Award.AwardTitle: East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Allison McInnes of Texas A&M University to conduct a research project, entitled "Using new techniques to understand the carbon cycle of the Eastern Indian Ocean" during the summer of 2012 at the University of Western Australia in Perth, Australia. The host scientist is Dr. Anya Waite.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is a better understanding of the oceanic carbon cycle in a unique and understudied region of the world's ocean. The phytoplankton community is being intensively sampled to provide accurate measurements of phytoplankton community composition and the amount of primary production and nitrogen fixation, for a more thorough understanding of how the base of the food web and primary producers of the ocean drive the carbon cycle. This region is characterized as having very low nutrients which are necessary for phytoplankton while also supporting many important fisheries. A better understanding the carbon cycle in this region reveals how an "oceanic desert" can support so much life.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

EAPSI: Using new techniques to understand the carbon cycle of the Eastern Indian Ocean

             Current estimates suggest that the world’s oceans are responsible for half of the drawdown of atmospheric carbon dioxide released by human activities. Phytoplankton (microalgae) are the plants of the sea and these organisms use carbon dioxide that is dissolved in the seawater plus light and nutrients (primarily nitrogen, phosphorous and silica) to grow (carbon fixation). Measurement of carbon fixation in the sea is difficult; as such there are many techniques to do so. Beyond quantification, determination of the fate (oceanic food web, or deep sea burial) of the fixed carbon is also important for understanding this global cycle.

            Oceanographers track the fate of organic matter by determining the source of the nitrogen used in carbon fixation. Regenerated nitrogen is the nitrogen that is recycled by microbes and other organisms in the surface ocean; this production keeps the system running at “normal” levels. New nitrogen comes from “external” sources including river runoff, nitrogen from deep water coming back to the surface (upwelling), and nitrogen fixation by organisms in the surface waters.

            The Indian Ocean is among the least studied portions of the global ocean. What we know of this system is that it is unique. It is confined primarily to the southern hemisphere; this geography has interesting consequences to the oceanography of the system including seasonal changes in dominant current regimes. In keeping with the dynamic nature of this ocean the Leeuwin Current (a major feature of the eastern Indian Ocean) is a globally unique eastern boundary current. Unlike most eastern boundary currents the Leeuwin Current is a warmer, less saline, poleward flowing current yielding a downwelling dominated coast (limited and seasonal upwelling). Further, there are few rivers that empty into the eastern Indian Ocean from the Australian continent, leaving the primary source of new nitrogen as nitrogen fixation. Because production that occurs as a result of nitrogen fixation is considered “new,” this production can be calculated as available for export; allowing us to make reasonable estimates of the amount of carbon sequestered in this region of the world ocean.

            The National Science Foundation East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute afforded me the opportunity to work with Professor Anya Waite at the University of Western Australia in this dynamic region. During my time here I have learned the latest techniques and shared my knowledge of new molecular techniques for measuring carbon and nitrogen fixation. Further, in collaboration with the University of Tasmania and Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) I was afforded the opportunity to participate in two oceanographic voyages in the eastern Indian Ocean aboard the Marine National Facility of Australia, the Southern Surveyor. On these voyages I collected samples to analyze using molecular techniques while Dr. Waite’s lab collected samples using traditional techniques. These data will offer great insight into the carbon cycling of the Eastern Indian Ocean, as these represent the first measurements of these processes in this region.
